summary: how to write lyrics like harry styles
title: how to write lyrics like harry styles
body:
as a poet/lyricist, harry styles is one of my favorite artists, mainly because of his lyrics. looking to emulate the style, i looked into patterns and tendencies that make his lyrics so appealing.

imagery
first, i’m gonna throw the big one out: imagery! as many writers know, imagery is all you need to make something good, really. harry goes very specific into his images though.
ex. “when she’s alone she goes home to a cactus, in a black dress, she’s such an actress” (Kiwi)
the more detail he gives, the easier it is to visualize and feel, which is what makes good poetry. of course, don’t describe every stand of hair on a girl, but knowing imagery is a good place to start. 

explaining the imagery
something else he does in, not all, but a few songs is give specific images then describe what they mean. in the second verse of “Two Ghosts”, for example, a line is “Fridge light washes this room white, / Moon dances over your good side, / This was all we used to need.”

He gives the image of a dark room with a little light from the moon and fridge, then explains why he’s giving such a strange image. It shows how that’s how it used to be between the two of them. 

first line
harry likes to use the tactic of throwing out something in the first line that’s specific and intriguing.
ex. “she’s got a family in carolina,” (carolina), “tell me something, tell me something / you don’t know nothing, just pretend you do” (ever since new york), “she worked her way through a cheap pack of cigarettes” (kiwi)
In the first lines of anything, we’re taught to have a hook- that was what I was taught in elementary school, at least- and i think harry has mastered that. he opens with a detail that he usually elaborates on in the first verse then connects to in the chorus, before moving onto another detail in the second verse. his songs are impossible to only listen to part of.

alluding
something else harry does is allude to other things and connect his songs together, making it intriguing and worth it to listen to multiple songs.
ex. alluding to 1d songs: “we’re just two ghosts swimming in a glass half empty” (harry styles, ‘two ghosts’), “we’re just swimming ‘round in our glasses and talking out of our asses” (one direction, ‘a.m.’)
ex. alluding to songs supposedly about him: “same lips red, same eyes blue, same white shirt, couple more tattoos.” (harry styles, ‘two ghosts’), “you’ve got that james dean daydream look in your eye/ i got that red lip classic thing that you like… you’ve got that long hair, slick back, white t-shirt” (taylor swift, ‘style’)
ex. alluding to other lyrics from himself: “just let me know i’ll be at the door, at the door / hoping you’ll come around / just let me know i’ll on the floor, on the floor / maybe we’ll work it out” (meet me in the hallway), “broke a finger knocking on your bedroom door, / i got splinters in my knuckles, crawling cross the floor” (only angel)

figurative language
i’m surprised we got this far into a lyrical post without mentioning this! figurative language is a key element to lyrical poetry and poetry in general, but, if you pay attention to harry’s lyrics, it’s mostly literal. the only metaphors i can think of him using are extended ones, such as in ‘medicine’, which is totally about sex, but it’s talked about as a medicine. he does have some scattered about, but never in excess.
in ‘from the dining table’, there is some personification in the line “even my phone misses your call”, but he doesn’t use much overall.
what he lacks in similes and metaphors, he makes up for with imagery. harry styles’ writing style is very literal, but isn’t completely void of it. 

titling songs
while titling songs, harry usually goes one of three approaches: either using the most important lyric, describing the setting either of the song or writing the song, or doing a cryptic thing that takes hella analysis. luckily, us fans are dedicated, but that’s a whole other approach.
the most important lyric is obvious. ‘two ghosts’ is titled that because it’s repeated in the chorus and ‘carolina’ gets it’s name from the fact it’s in the first line. most songwriters use this method, with good reason to.
the next is a little more than that. ‘ever since new york’ shows that the feelings he’s describing in the song are what’s occurring after an incident in new york and when i hear ‘from the dining table’ i picture harry at a wooden table writing a letter to someone he misses. i use this approach to titling things very often, but harry is one of the only bigger artists i can think of who does this. 
the cryptic titles are confusing to explain. an example of this is ‘kiwi’, which could represent a lot. the girl he describes in this song be compared to a kiwi either because she’s ‘sweet yet sour’ or because she’s a new zealand native. it leaves a lot of room for mystery that requires more looking into than others.

that’s all i got folks! there’s more stuff to get into with melody and vocals, but, hey, i’m just a writer!

don’t expect to write a song perfectly in his style, but do pay extra attention to some of these elements while writing if you want to try and emulate his style or combine it with your own!

here is a song i wrote in attempt to merge his lyrical style with my own, and while it’s not the best thing i’ve ever written, i’m happy with the result! :)

title: Deception ↠ H.S
body:
“I thought you were dead.”

003

1:55pmI scrubbed at the last plate in the sink, soapy water splattering on my dress.I couldn’t stop thinking about Harry. Him and his dumbfounded face when I went off on him this morning.He can’t…

Read more…

reblog.comment:
“I thought you were dead.”
